content: Dan Choi Shoots Down Every Don't Ask Don't Tell Argument *****TY Q&A — While U.S. Army First Lieutenant Dan Choi waits — like so many other gay soldiers — for President Barack Obama and Congress to kill Don't Ask Don't Tell, he's taken the lead as one of the most prominent openly gay service members to campaign for the policy's repeal. In a personal chat with *****ty's David Hauslaib, the Arabic linguist reveals he's as committed as ever to serving his country — if only we would let him. Full article with video found here ... >>>http://www.*****ty.com/exclusive-dan-choi-shoots-down-every-dont-ask-dont-tell-argument-20090512/

title: Dan Choi Shoots Down Every Don't Ask Don't Tell Argument

content: Lt. Choi Attends Defense Testimony Gay service member Lt. Dan Choi and representatives from the Servicemembers Legal Defense Network attended the Department of Defense 2010 budget hearing Wednesday at which Defense secretary Bob Gates and Joint Chiefs chairman Mike Mullen testified in front of the House Armed Services Committee. Following the hearing, Lieutenant Choi approached Admiral Mullen and introduced himself. "I said, 'I'm Lt. Dan Choi and I'm being discharged under 'don't ask, don't tell.'" According to Choi, Mullen responded, "Oh, I know, I've seen you in the news," then listened as Choi added, "My intent is to fight [the discharge], to continue serving, and understand that if I do get kicked out, I'll be the first person in the recruiting station when they do repeal it." Choi called Mullen's reaction "warm and professional." "What I want to do is just allow my leaders to understand the situation more fully," Choi said, explaining the encounter. "Leadership always makes the best decisions when they have the full information." >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid83992.asp

Choi called Mullen's reaction "warm and professional." "What I want to do is just allow my leaders to understand the situation more fully," Choi said, explaining the encounter. "Leadership always makes the best decisions when they have the full information." >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid83992.asp

According to Choi, Mullen responded, "Oh, I know, I've seen you in the news," then listened as Choi added, "My intent is to fight [the discharge], to continue serving, and understand that if I do get kicked out, I'll be the first person in the recruiting station when they do repeal it." Choi called Mullen's reaction "warm and professional." "What I want to do is just allow my leaders to understand the situation more fully," Choi said, explaining the encounter. "Leadership always makes the best decisions when they have the full information." >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid83992.asp
title: Dan Choi Shoots Down Every Don't Ask Don't Tell Argument
